body.p: So far, we’ve dealt with the case where we have only one explanatory variable, X, and one response variable, Y, both of which were quantitative. Broadly speaking, our two main goals were:

ol.li: Explore the nature of the relationship between X and Y and assess whether we can generalize the observed pattern from the sample to the entire population.
Assess the importance of the explanatory variable X as a predictor for Y, and quantify the strength of such a prediction.

body.p: As you remember, what enabled us to pursue our goals and was at the center of our entire analysis was the statistical model. As we discussed, this model is a simple approximation for how variables relate in the population which made sense based on the observed data.
When the observed the following pattern in the data:

image.alt: scatterplot showing a straight linear relationship

body.p: It made sense to assume the simple linear regression model:

image.alt: formula: y equals beta sub 0 plus beta sub 1 x plus epsilon

body.p: which assumes that the relationship between X and Y in the population follows a linear pattern, and that the data points follow this general pattern but not perfectly; we recognized that there are some deviations from the pattern. We further made some assumptions about the behavior of the deviations, and in particular we quantified their magnitude by their standard deviation σ.
When we observed the following pattern in the data,

image.alt: scatterplot showing a curved relationship starting in the upper left corner moving down and curving back up slightly in the lower right.

body.p: It made sense to assume the quadratic regression model:

image.alt: formula: y equals beta sub 0 plus beta sub 1 x plus beta sub 2 x squared plus epsilon

body.p: which assumes that the relationship between X and Y in the population follows a quadratic pattern, and, again, that the data points follow this general pattern but not perfectly.

In the remainder of this regression module, we are moving multiple regression, where we explore the relationship between the response variable Y and several explanatory variables: X1, X2, …,Xk, . We will ask interesting questions such as:

ul.li: How can we use all the explanatory variables collectively to predict the response Y?
Are all out explanatory variables really relevant (or important) for the purpose of predicting Y?
Do all the explanatory variables have to be quantitative, or can we include some categorical explanatory variables as well?
If we start with a lot of explanatory variables, is there some systematic method that will give us the “best” subset of explanatory variables among them.

body.p: The only down side of multiple regression compared to dealing with only one explanatory variable is that we loose the ability to easily visualize all data in a way that will lead us to coming up with a statistical model that makes sense. To illustrate this point, consider the following hypothetical example.

example.p: In an effort to be able to effectively predict a students’ score in a second statistics course (Stats2), an instructor collected data from 100 students who have just completed the course.

ul.li:
The two explanatory variables are:
X1 – SAT-M score
X2 – Stats 1 course score,

and the response:
Y- Stats2 course score

image.alt: data table displaying raw data for all variables

example.p: In this, simplest case of multiple regression (in the sense that we have only two explanatory variables), we can plot the data in a a “3D scatterplot”:

image.alt: 3D scatterplot displaying the relationship of y to both explanatory variables

example.p: However, as you can see there is really not much information that we can gain from looking at the graph regarding the relationship between X1, X2 and Y, and in particular, the plot does not help us in determining what would be a reasonable model to use.
Furthermore, once we add another, third, explanatory variable, then there is really no way that we can visualize the entire data.
As we’ll see there are ways to “overcome” this problem and the do the best we can.
On the upside, multiple regression will allow us to analyze much more complex datasets and will further expose us to the power of data analysis in extracting useful information from data.
